prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: When it comes to departing and departed employees, it is often difficult to know how the competing principles set forth in this chapter will be harmonized. In fact, in some cases, it may be impossible to predict the level of employee and the type of behaviour that will fall under censure. However, it is possible to set forth a number of principles. A number of case law developments have had a significant impact by reiterating existing principles and clarifying various aspects of the law. Most notable are the ongoing influence of the Supreme Court of Canada's decisions in LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[1] Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd.[2] and RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc.,[3] and the Court of Appeal cases in Lyons v. Multari[4] (Ontario) and Felker v. Cunningham[5] (Ontario).

It is normally true that the “mere employee”, in the absence of improper activity prior to departure from employment or absent the misuse of information of an obviously confidential nature, will be free to compete directly with the former employer. Such competition will include the ability to directly solicit customers of the former employer.

It is equally true that an employer will be able to protect its confidential information, such as information relating to customers, from being disclosed or improperly used by existing and former employees. Employees who have signed employment agreements containing valid restrictive covenants regarding confidentiality, non-solicitation or non-competition, and those owing fiduciary obligations, will have stricter and expanded duties.

In attempting to enunciate the various rights of the parties to litigation, it is always necessary to keep in mind that two competing interests are at stake. The courts have consistently acknowledged the vital importance of both of these interests. First, in a free enterprise society, the departing employee has the right to compete with his or her former employer and to make use of the knowledge and skill acquired during the course of the employment relationship. On the other hand, the employer has the right to protect confidential business information and to be free from the improper solicitation of customers.

The courts have sought to enforce minimum standards of good faith and fair dealing, and to recognize that by restraining the use of certain information, important economic interests are maintained. The effort to restrict the use of certain information is an acknowledgment of the broader principle that prohibits acts contrary to general honesty in industrial and commercial practice. Generally the courts have had little trouble in protecting the misuse or disclosure of confidential information, where there has been demonstrated unfairness by a departed employee.
By way of summary, in balancing the competing interests of employers and employees, the courts will consider each of the following sets of issues:

Did the employee serve the employer in good faith throughout the employment relationship? Prior to departing from the employment, did the former employee do anything dishonest or improper? Was there a misuse of company resources?
In the circumstances of the departure, did the employee act reasonably? Did the employee give adequate and proper notice?[6] How easily can the employee be replaced?
In the circumstances of the departure, did the employer act reasonably?
Was there any misuse of any confidential information by the employee? Or, is the employee simply making use of the knowledge and skills acquired during the course of the employment relationship?[7]
Has there been any solicitation of the employer's customers? In the circumstances, what kind of solicitation is proper? What are the interests of the customers or clients?

Are the duties of the employee to the former employer heightened by any express terms contained in the employment contract? Is there a restrictive covenant that binds the employee following departure? When was the covenant signed? Was adequate consideration given to the employee? Is the covenant enforceable in the circumstances?

Are the duties of the former employee heightened by any implied contractual terms? Does the individual fact situation—including the employee's position, the specific business or the nature and practice of the industry—say anything about the terms of the employment?
Are the duties of the employee to the former employer heightened because the employee falls within the class of individuals owing the employer a fiduciary duty?

In all the circumstances, what is the fair way to remedy the dispute and balance the interests of the parties? Will the employee be prevented from earning a livelihood? Will the interests of the employer be adequately protected?
For what length of time should the employee's obligations to the former employer continue?
